stem: A client with a T4 spinal cord injury (SCI) reports a 'pounding' headache and blurred vision. Based on the documentation in the SCI Surveillance & Vital Signs Log, what is the nurse's first priority action?

tabs.title: Nursing Physical
tabs.content: Current Findings: Skin is flushed and diaphoretic above the T4 level (face/neck). Skin is pale and cool below the T4 level. Foley catheter bag has 0 mL of output for the last 4 hours.

tabs.title: SBAR Context
tabs.content: Note: Client has a history of T4 complete transection. Currently lying flat in bed for a wound dressing change.

options.text: Elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees (High-Fowler's)
Irrigate the Foley catheter to rule out obstruction

rationale.correct: This is **Autonomic Dysreflexia (a1)**, a life-threatening emergency in patients with SCI at T6 or above. The massive BP spike (218/112) is often triggered by a full bladder or bowel. The **first priority** is always to **sit the patient up (a1)** to allow for orthostatic gravity to help lower the intracranial/blood pressure. Only after sitting them up should the nurse check for the trigger (e.g., kinked foley, fecal impaction).
clinicalPearls: Autonomic Dysreflexia = BP Up. HR Down. T6 injury or higher.
Above the injury: Flushed, sweating, nasal congestion. Below the injury: Pale, cold.
Most common cause: Bladder distension (foley kink).

questionTrap.trap: Choosing to fix the foley (a2) or give meds (a3) first.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In the NCLEX 'Priority Action' hierarchy, **Positioning** (the fastest, non-invasive fix) usually comes before interventions or notifications. Sitting them up is the 'antidote' to the pressure spike.

mnemonic.title: Head-Up
mnemonic.expansion: Head is Pounding? Head is Up! (90 degrees).
